p: GWAS have identified 28 distinct loci that modify the individual risk to PD [ 85] and suggest that genetic factors contribute to at least one-fourth of the total variation in liability to PD [ 86]. The two most consistent genes for susceptibility to sporadic PD are the alpha-synuclein (SNCA) and microtubule-associated protein tau (MAPT) genes, which can exert independent or joint effects on the risk of PD [ 56, 59, 61, 62, 87]. In addition, variants in other genes previously linked with autosomal forms (LRRK2, PARK16–18, and GBA) have also shown association with PD risk [ 64, 88– 90]. Based on odds ratio and confidence intervals values in the selected studies, thirty-nine different SNPs in the SNCA gene showed a statistically significant effect on PD susceptibility: nine variants in the 5′ end, nine variants near the 3′ end, and 25 intron variants ( Table 2).
